mdRecord.dcterms:title: The Eagle, general view
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Saint-Gaudens, Louis (American sculptor, 1854-1913) [work]
Wilson, Richard Guy [photographer]
mdRecord.dcterms:publisher: Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia
mdRecord.dcterms:description: This Louis Saint-Gaudens piece depicts an eagle feeding an unfortunate snake to her chicks in their nest. The Eagle statue originally stood over the entrance to the New York Life Insurance Company building in Omaha, Nebraska. A near-duplicate exists on the New York Life Insurance building in Kansas City, Missouri. At some unknown point, the Omaha eagle was moved to the entrance of an annex building of the First National Bank of Omaha which by then also owned the original building. At a later unknown date (possibly around 1978), the statue was returned to the entrance of the original New York Life building when the structure was restored and had become the headquarters of Kutak Rock Law Firm. See: http://www.publicartomaha.org/art/info/127/The%20Eagle [work]
